description.text: Assassin's creed symbol made for a necklace.

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=279864 El fichero "customizable_tree..." es fichero original generado con el "customizer" pero su tamaño es demasiado pequeño, yo necesitaba un tamaño mayor, el cual no podía ser imprimido con la impresora. Por ello el árbol lo escalé a 2,4 veces el tamaño y lo dividí en partes para su impresión obteniendo en total 20 partes, las cuales han sido pegadas con acetona ya que está imprimido en ABS y reforzadas con pegamento de cianocrilato, con la ventaja que no hizo falta material de soporte para su impresión. El árból es hueco y se ha imprimido con una boquilla y una altura de capa de 0,4mm y un grosor de pared de tres filas, quizás cuatro filas hubiera estado mejor para conseguir más superficie de contacto en las ramas inclinadas ya que algunas han quedado algo débiles.

This is a toy tug boat I designed to make for my nephews and nieces for Christmas. I have a duel extruder on my Ultimaker so part 1 is one color and part 2 is the other. Its 165 mm form bow to stern but scales well. I have printed it at 30mm, 80, mm and 160mm. If you make one please post a pic. This is my first build so let me know what you think.
V2 has sloped sides.
V2 Updated 10/20/2014. Noticed deck walls at boats widest point were a little thin.
V2 Updated 10/22/2014 removed gap between cab and deck.
If you have trouble with model let me know and I will try to fix it.

I printed with 15 % fill 0.8 mm wall thickness and 1.2mm top and bottom thickness. Not sure how well it would float with 100% fill. If you don't have a duel extruder for your printer you will want to download one of the whole models

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Y Axis Extension Plate 1403

description.text:
Here is a plate I made to complete my Build Volume Upgrade on the Printrbot simple metal 1403.  This allow for around 290mm of travel on the Y axis.  It just Bolts to the back of the arm to extend the mounting holes back.  You will need longer 8mm Polished Drill Rod, and a longer GT2 Belt. 3 M3 Screws and Bolts to attach.  I made this as a mockup for a friend to reproduce it in aluminum for me but the PLA print is working perfect.  
Update: Added a 4" version as requested.
Update: Added a Version for 400mm Rods instead of the stock 395mm

Rod Used:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/8mm-smooth-Drill-Rod-36-Long-for-linear-bearings-mendel-reprap-Rostock-3d-/231078456678?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item35cd596d66 This is what I used to cut both sections out of, you will have about a 1" or so piece left. You will need around a 450 mm piece of GT2 Timing Belt. I recommend a 3 ft piece and cut so that is enough to do the X axis also if you wish. After the belt and rods are on you can set your new travel limits with the manual G-code entry section: M208 Y290 (Sets 290 mm travel on the Y Axis) M500 (To Save) M501 (To Display results) The M208 line should reflect the size of your new print area. Example it should display: M208 X152.4 Y290 Z152.4 if this is the only upgrade you do to the stock Simple Metal. Set the new Y axis print bed size in your printer / slicer program settings and you are ready to print!

comments.text: Is the bed pictured heated? I currently have the heated bed for the extended X axis upgrade printrbot.  The new bed for this upgrade means quite a  but more metal to heat and I was wondering what anyones's experience has been.  Did you get a larger heatbed?  If so how large?  If not how much does it increase heat up time and/or max temp?
comments.author: DrRadium

comments.text: I made my own as it was cheaper and did not have to wait for it. I used resistance wire and a thermistor. The wait time for heating to 50c is about 10 mins so i would say substantially longer than a smaller bed. Max temp was about 80c.

author: joeydaphish

description.text:
The Bilge pump thruster is a great way to mount a bilge pump to an 1/2"PVC frame. The quill mounting system will fit into a fitting or into the 1/2" tube. Now included are the scad files. Mount is parametic, so feel free to edit for you needs. The two and three blade propellers available on thingiverse. These fit with around 2mm of clearance between the cowling and propeller. The text writing credit goes to HARLANDMII for his write.scad program.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193

We use support and print with the end that mounts to the motor down.  Previous versions built out from the pillars and did not require support to print. We found that this build out significantly reduced the volume of water that was able to reach the propeller.   
The mount is held onto the motor with a 10-24 x 1" bolt and lock nut. The quill is held together with a 8-32 x 1 1/4" bolt and lock nut in the base of the quill.   
There are two options for mounting. You can mount directly into a 1/2 PVC fitting using the bottomwedge_tee and middlewedge_tee, or glue a 1/2 tube into your fitting and use the bottomwedge_tube and middlewedge_tube. We have found using the tube wedges gave slightly better holding power.  
The motor used is a Johnson Cartridge Bilge Pump 500 gallon per hour. Model 2855

description.text:
Difficulty level: Advanced (see disclaimer at end). I've listed the parts and approaches that I've used, and my results so far. I think the project is at the point where others might find it worth considering for more advanced setups. It grew out of an Instructable: http://www.instructables.com/id/Coffee-Cup-PCR-Thermocycler-costing-under-350/
You might also look at the BioHacking explanation webpage at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biohacking and the brilliant work at Open PCR http://openpcr.org/

description.header: The idea is to explore a 3D printed enclosure for this module.  The possibilities seem almost limitless.  I can print new designs for enclosures as fast as I can CAD them up.  Hope this information helps in your approaches.
description.text:
This project seeks to configure a 3D-printed, USB powered, remotely accessed, disposable, low cost - Real Time Quantitative PCR (qPCR or RTPCR) module. Background: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) has revolutionized broad areas of forensics, medicine, biology and field research. Unfortunately Real Time (RT) PCR platforms which are able to track and display the amplification of DNA samples during a PCR procedure remain prohibitively expensive. The development of a 3D printed, low cost USB powered remotely accessed system for under 220$ would be a tremendous advantage for research, medicine and education. What makes this project interesting?: 1.Broad range of applications with significant impact on education and research.
2.Novel 3D printable Design features
3.Combination of low cost technologies
4.Providing access to Research technology
  • Ruggedized system for field research
    • A unique aspect of this project is that the development of a low cost portable RT-PCR module would span many levels of many types educational application. These range from training young scientists in high school programs, through affordable teaching capabilities in molecular and biological science laboratories in graduate school settings, to postgraduate research laboratories and include ruggedized and portable field research applications. The goal is to provide a portable USB powered RT-PCR module at a cost below 220$ and to provide this configuration with educational content, possibly in association with a biopharmaceutical corporation. The objective is to provide this system not only at an affordable cost for academic programs but also to â€œruggedizeâ€ the module for use in biomedical, environmental and field research settings. Ideally the unit could be run with a parallax Basic stamp module, an LCD screen and a minty boost power supply. Initial tests have demonstrated acceptable thermal cycling (even without styrofoam insulation) and properly timed light level monitoring based on thermal cycling. The Labview graphical software platform makes it easy to tweak the capabilities and develop high end user interfaces. I'm currently tweaking the Light sensing keyed on Temperature reading in a separate graph. Disclaimer: This is my experience. I'm not telling you what to do, just what I did. If you try this and brick your computer, then its on you. No seriously, I mean that part. This project is intended to explore the capabilities of low cost RT PCR on a 3D printed platform and is not intended for diagnostic or field research use. It is only intended for educational, instructive or illustrative uses.

Current project phase: Project is a "work in progress". Currently writing Light level sensing in Labview, based on cycle temperature with separate light level graph and data logging to txt file. Would also like to find a more sensitive light sensor, maybe a PMT (photo multiplier tube) but want to stay with the USB power only challenge. Might use a phidget light sensor. One limitation is that this is a single sample only module. I might like to make it a four sample system. With 3D printing that's a breeze. Instructions and Parts list: 1) Assemble electronic parts.
2) Write control program in LABVIEW (or Basic stamp module with LCD screen)
3) Print out a 3D housing/Enclosure for the module (Hexagonal box with lid).
3) Drill hole for LED, for sample tube in top and hole for the Band pass filter holder to sit in.
The band pass filter sits over the Photoresistor, between the sample and photoresistor.
4) Do some cool experiments
  • Notice that when a 0.2 ml PCR tube sits in the top sample hole, the LED light shines onto the tube at and angle and that the BAND pass filter is out of the direct line of the LED beam. The internal angles of the hexagon are 120 degrees. These angle converge on the sample tube while the Minco Thermofoil heaters are on the front and back sides of the enclosure.
    • Parts List:
  • Temp sensor [1051_2 - PhidgetTemperatureSensor 1-Input 60$]
  • Thermocouple [3109_0 - TPK-01G Bead Probe K-type (-50Â°C to +450Â°C) 12$]
  • Heaters [Minco heaters low voltage [MINCO HK5561R37.4 L12B 0021 two from Ebay 25$]
  • Cables [old USB cables from previous projects - free]
  • Relays [3053_0 - Dual SSR Relay Board 30$]
  • Photoresistor [ bag full from ebay 2$]
  • Phidget voltage divider [1121_0 - Voltage Divider 7$] adjustable sensitivity
  • Band pass filter [Edmund optics Filter INT 532 or 535 nm 11.80 mm Diameter 25$]
  • Control program [Labview]
  • 2/2/2 2 digital in, 2 digital out, 2 analog in board [1011_0 - PhidgetInterfaceKit 2/2/2 50$]
  • LED [emits the wavelength for SYBER green fluorescence (Aqua 497) 10$ for a few].
    Remember you could also use an infrared LED, but might be some secondary peaks.
    • Total cost for parts 50+25+1+30+25+12+60+2+10=215$ (not counting LABVIEW or 3D printer)
  • If you don't have either a 3D printer or Labview graphical programming platform then consider using an Altoid Minty boost as a power supply (good for 30 thermal cycles) and a Parallax Board of education (Basic stamp) with an LCD screen. The programming is straight forward just keep your "Big Picture" overview in mind and draw what you want the BASIC program to do on a black board. Then take it one part or step at a time and test each capability. Its really not as complicated as it seems. Just remember to turn on the LED and to take a Light reading at the same temperature on the way up a temp curve and on the way down, to see the differences.
    • Disclaimer: This is my experience. I'm not telling you what to do, just what I did. If you try this and brick your computer, then its on you. No seriously, I mean that part. This project is intended to explore the capabilities of low cost RT PCR on a 3D printed platform and is not intended for diagnostic or field research use. It IS intended for educational, instructive or illustrative uses.

comments.text: Use an avalanche photodiode an a instrumentation amp if you want any hope of detecting very low light levels. I've used miniature PMT modules, but they cost over $400 each. Ambient light will also be a problem for you as the plastic isn't opaque. Do some research on existing instrumentation to see the type of detectors that are in use. Your idea is very good, but the fact that you chose a cadmium sulfide cell as a detector tells me you need to do a lot more research to help avoid frustration in the future.

title: Bendy Articulated Arm For Those Awkward Octopus Position (FreeCAD files included for remix)

description.text:
This is an articulated arm for 40mm fan mount for cooling filament from hot nozzle but can otherwise be remixed for other purpose. As it is meant for the Velleman K8200 (3Drag) 3D printer, this thing includes a mount that fits over an original part (the fan mount on frame) within the kit for extra snuggyness. C D Beam provides 180 degrees action.
C Beam is more sturdy but has fewer degrees of freedom.
Ball Beam is an extension beam. Fixing screw holes are M3, but holding them together with rubber band will do just fine. All STL has a flat surface for positioning on print bed. FreeCAD files provide for remix!
K8200 fan nozzle is from original STL file.
The orange is from my star ship replicator.

The parts with ball joint should ideally be print with 0.2mm layer thickness (or less).   
Using Cura, on the advance tab, 'cutoff object bottom' by 0.3mm to improve adhesion to printing bed. If that too fails, use 'UHU extra power' glue stick shown in gallery.  
And don't forget to have fun! LOLZ of fun!

title: Handlebar / tube mount for Garmin Montana 600 family

description.text: This holds a Garmin GPS device on one of my two bikes for the forthcoming holidays. It is sturdier than I thought (see http://youtu.be/WCfcyDthPXo)

I uploaded here 3 different sets (where 31.8 reaches the maximum) because the customizer could not handle the DXF profile of the GPS device. They should match the main handlebar diameters (according to the wikipedia), else tweak it with Openscad (source included as usual) Select your handlebar diameter (works up to ~31mm fat bars), then print two "arm" STL and one "nut" STL file. It uses M3 screws. It slices neatly on an ultimaker with the following parameters:
  • 0.2 mm layers
  • 1.8 mm walls (loops->infill->perimeters)
  • 1.2mm bottom/top
  • 30% fill

This is a case I designed to be printed in flexible filament to house the Polaroid Cube action cam for extra protection as well as allowing for velcro straps to be used for attaching it to non magnetic materials.

This must be made with either Ninjaflex or some other flexible filament.  No support should be required.  
It's a tight fit to get in, and even more difficult to get out so I ended up snipping the middle of one of the walls where it's inserted.  With 100% infill it's still very secure, but allows for easier removal.

**update Dec 23, 2014 - Uploaded a thicker whistle which can get louder notes An improved Shepherd's whistle with a handle to thread a string through and hold while playing. A whistle commonly used by Shepherd's for giving commands to dogs. These things require a bit of practice to use, but can be very loud and fun once you get the hang of them. Once you get good at playing it, you can make many different tones with it! If you don't know how to play a shepherd's whistle, this guy does a short explanation and then plays one very nicely: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mv66viUCn1Y Optional sound improvement: After printing run a utility knife through the open slot of the whistle to get rid of any thin strands of plastic that may have worked their way in there when printing. You can also try sanding the outside flat surfaced with a medium grit (#120) sandpaper and then move on to extra fine grit (#240).... but it's not really necessary.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

.3mm

title: Glass clips for Printrbot Simple Metal with mic6 aluminum heatbed

description.text: These are clips I made to hold down a 6"x8", 1/8" thick borosilicate glass pane I got for my PB Simple Metal that has the mic6 aluminum heat bed upgrade. These use the four outermost bolts that attach the wings of the bed to the aluminum part. I had to get longer M3 screws to attach the clips. I've included the .stl file that contains both sides (it will need to be printed twice to get a full set) and also the .stl files for the two sides separately, just in case. After making the first clips (pictured) with PLA, I discovered after a few prints they began to warp from the heat so the screws kept coming loose. I reprinted them in ABS and they have been holding up well, so I recommend ABS for these. UPDATE: Printrbot has released a bed insulator kit for this heat bed. It includes a foil sheet to help insulate the bed, as well as delrin spacers to add more clearance underneath the bed, and spacers to isolate the steel wings from the aluminum. The spacers for the wings create a "step" between the aluminum and steel. I've added glass_clips w/delrin spacers.stl for download that adds a "step" to the clips to compensate. If you do not have the spacers, download the original .stl file.

comments.text: Oh no! That sucks! Yeah, I don't know if you bought your printer fully assembled or as a kit. I bought mine as a kit, and hooked the probe up backwards the first time as well. It fried the probe, and I had to wait an extra week to start printing while I got a replacement shipped out. Only after that mistake did I read in the instructions from Printrbot that black does NOT go to black on the extension wire from the board to the probe. They say hooking it up backwards will fry the probe. Strange that your board fried. Never heard of that happening before.
comments.author: rhduggan

comments.text: I bought mine assembled. I didn't do black to black. I did (probe to board) black to red, brown to white, blue to black, just the way the inductive probe was hooked up. I did hear a pop and a small puff of smoke came from the pot on the probe first as soon as I started to (gently - I do have experience with these things) adjust the pot, before I could get to the switch on the power supply it was smoking from underneath. The smoke was coming from the end of the board where the screw connector for the heater is. I'm guessing it's a power transistor that burned up, but I won't know for sure until I pull the board off. I'm not going to do that until a new board, which I just ordered, arrives from Printrbot. This is killing me; my kids and I were having so much fun.
comments.author: JG094

comments.text: For continuity's sake, my Printrboard is the rev F without the "probe adapter board". I wonder if you had a rev D? Not sure that that would make a difference though. Also, I took the probe out of my printer to double check. I've got a LJC12A3-H-Z/BY PNP 6-36VDC 300mA probe. You can test the probe with a 9 volt battery (these sensors work from 6-36 volts), some leads, and a multimeter (or a small lightbulb works too). These PNP capacitive sensors are pretty much all the same internally. The brown wire is V+ (the positive on your 9v battery), the blue wire is the ground (negative on your 9v battery), and the black wire is the signal wire. To test the probe, hook brown to positive, blue to negative, and you'll test operation with the black wire. When the light on the probe is off (nothing is being detected), you should get a reading of 9 volts between the brown and blue wires. When the light is on (probe is detecting something), you should get a 9 volt reading between the blue and black wires. I found a video that may be of more help than me trying to explain it. Give it a watch if you like. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PtwquSJ1zgw
comments.author: rhduggan

comments.text: You took your printer apart? I really appreciate you're going to such extent! I don't know if the difference between the H and the 5 should make any difference, but the specs of the probe I have are supposedly the same. I'll do the battery test when the other one I have ordered arrives, but I'm not sure I'll be willing to install it on my machine once it's repaired. My fried board is Rev F 4. Thanks for all your help!
comments.author: JG094

comments.text: No problem. Happy to try and help! Let me know if you need any more assistance. That's one benefit of having built this thing from a kit. I know it inside and out! haha
comments.author: rhduggan

comments.text: Are there any issues with the leveling probe detecting the metal through the glass?  I'm curious how close your probe is to the glass when it detects the print bed and what your M212 settings are.
comments.author: Galaktican

comments.text:
To Galaktican and anyone else who is interested:
I got this capacitive probe (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008MU0G9A/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1), and I can confirm that it does work to detect the glass, and it has been repeatable on each one of the prints I've done in the past couple days. This probe has a potentiometer that adjusts the sensing distance from 1mm-5mm. It will most likely need to be adjusted to sense farther out (mine was set to the shortest range out of the box), but it perfectly detects glass at the same distance (or farther) than the stock inductive probe did.
comments.author: Galaktican

comments.text: Yes, right now the "stock" inductive leveling probe doesn't work with the glass- it is too far away, even with the probe touching the glass. I am waiting for a capacitive probe (with the same dimensions as the inductive probe) in the mail, which should detect the glass. I'll let you know what happens when I get the probe and do some testing. If it does work, it will be a great alternative to the inductive probe, and it can be had for $10.
comments.author: Galaktican

Clamps to fix material during CNC machine work.

Uploaded STL's are designed for material of 19mm thickness.
Testprinted in ABS. Two clamps on the same side of the material gave enough grip so I hardly couldn't move the material so I'm sure having clamps on 3-4 sides of the material will be more than enough to hold it tight.
M4 machine screws are used to mount it to my CNC table (MDF with drilled holes). 
One model with ha single hole (fixed distance for mounting material parallell to the drilled holes which was drilled by the machine and should be perfect parallell to the gantry).
The other uploaded STL model has a slot for the screw to be able to freely mount it.
The two meassurements circled in blue on the drawing are the important ones. 19mm which is the material height and 3mm which was the flex for a tight grip. Should probably work fine for material 17-19mm thick. The ABS is flexible and was pulling down the material enough so it didn't neither break the plastic or destroyed the drill holes.

description.text: A telescopic adjustable mount for a Z axis endstop microswitch

Print and assemble. Turn the screw to adjust.
M4 bolt 50mm + M4 nut + 3xM4 washers
M3 bolt 20mm + M3 nut + M3 washer
2xM2.5 bolts 20mm + 2xM2.5 nuts + 2xM2.5 washers (though can use M3 for these)
Short spring that fits M4 bolt The print is in two parts, the clamp and the switch mount. Print in ABS.
Thread the M4 bolt as follows:
M4 washer, clamp, M4 washer, spring, M4 washer, switch mount, M4 nut
Now as you tighten and loosen the bolt the height should change.
Mount under the X-axis gantry as shown I usually use a hall-effect switch but recently been having reliability issues with it, and wanted a way of getting a similar fine-tuning effect. Use z-switchr.stl if you want to put the bolt thru from the top instead of the bottom - depends on your X-end clearance
Table saw or shop saw push stick.  All original files are included so if you want to make changes feel free!

I printed this on my Maker Bot Replicator 5th Generation.
I used 11% infill and 5 shells with a raft. I think it would work without a raft though.

comments.author: PolakiumEngineering

comments.text: The duct has been working very well for me so far, but I only recently finished the design and started making use of it. I printed mine with PLA and I have noticed that hotend temps above 230C are nearly enough to begin softening the thinner plastic walls, but I have already thought of a solution to this which I intend to upload later if it works. Although I am using the standard Ubis hotend, I intend to eventually upgrade to the all-metal hotend; therefore, I have designed the duct to potentially work with both and perhaps provide adequate airflow for properly cooling the barrel with a single fan. That may not be a practical solution, but I won't know until I have tested it with the all-metal hotend. In the time being, it has worked very well with my standard ubis hotend and I have had no issue sustaining the temperatures.

Hey friends.
I prepair a project from summer 2014 for public. My intension was to do a complete set of water rocket launcher.
My test setting was proof up to 15 Bar/ 220 PSI which was my goal.
I tested with rockets sized from 0.5 liters up to 9 liters. Please give comments.
I am open for special wishes and ideas. Parts are tested an everithing works good but I want to do some additional features like guiding rails for a better start performance. So this is work in process!

For the bottleadapter:
You need to print with minimum 3 perimeters at 0.4mm nozzle.
For release_body infill I did take honeycomb pattern at 6%. As you can see at the photo I used a gasket of a beer bottle. The fins are each in two parts. You need to glue them together.
Use them (allways three) with "bottleadapter_11mm_fin_1". Zip tie at the opposite side. The funnel is really helpfull to fill water into the bottles. For a good tight fit of the bottleadapter you can scale it by 1% up, or down. Maybe use teflon strip.
I printed in ABS an fitted it with acetone.

title: Z-Box Anti-Wobble & Anti-Backlash 1.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: (in english... below...)

description.header: Una THING! per stampanti 3D Open Source.
Vuoi eliminare i disturbi di BACKLASH (gioco del dado) e WOBBLE (oscillazioni della barra)  dell'asse Z con una sola modifica? Allora questa THING! fa per te!

description.text:
La parte centrale serve per eliminare il BACKLASH mantenendo spinti tra loro i due dadi, mentre la parte esterna serve per ammortizzare il WOBBLE tramite piccole molle che mantengono sospesa la parte centrale.  
Provala!

PS:
Per chi possiede la 3DRAG, la Z-Box ha un ingombro diverso dal più semplice pezzo originale; a breve saranno pronti i supporti per poterla utilizzare sulla 3DRAG.
(in english... translated by 3D-ME = Kyle Randall... thank you, Kyle!!!)

description.header: A Thing for Open Source 3D Printers (RepRaps).
Do you want to eliminate the BACKLASH (by the nut) and WOBBLE (by the rod) of the Z-axis with a single modification? If so, this Thing is for you!

description.text:
The center part of the box is used to eliminate the BACKLASH by keeping the two Z axis nuts pushed away from each other while the outside part is used to stabilize the WOBBLE by using small springs that keep it suspended around the central part of the box.  
Try it!

PS:
For those who own the 3DRAG, the Z-Box has a footprint dimension different than the original design. I designed new supports to realign the rod, so that we can use it.
(in english... below...)

Ti servono:
  • 2 dadi (8mm di diametro, io ho preferito usare quelli di ottone)
  • 2 rondelle piane (8mm di diametro)
  • 1 molla a compressione (10mm di diametro interno, 22mm di lunghezza, l'importante è che, la molla, compressa a circa 18cm di lunghezza eserciti una spinta non superiore a 0,5Kg, perché una forza maggiore spingerebbe troppo i due dadi e comprometterebbe la fluidità della rotazione della M8)
  • 4 viti (3mm di diametro, 40mm di lunghezza)
  • 4 rondelle piane (3mm di diametro)
  • 4 dadi (3mm di diametro)
  • 8 viti (3mm di diametro, 20mm di lunghezza)
  • 8 rondelle piane (3mm di diametro)
  • 8 rondelle dentellate (3mm di diametro)
  • 8 dadi (3mm di diametro)
  • 8 molle a compressione (4mm di diamtero esterno, 10mm di lunghezza)
  • 2 viti (5mm di diametro, 50mm di lunghezza)

Devi stampare:
  • Mod1a (1 copia)
  • Mod1b (2 copie)
  • Mod1c (1 copia)
  • Mod1d (1 copia)
  • Mod2a (2 copie)
  • Mod2b (2 copie)
  • Mod2c (2 copie)
  • Mod2d (1 copia)
Nella gallery  ho messo 15 foto con la sequenza di montaggio.

N.B.
Una volta finito l'assemblaggio e inserita sulla barra, la Z-Box deve ruotare liberamente, senza sforzo. Per capirci, tenendo in mano la barra verticalmente, deve bastare una leggera spinta laterale perchè la Z-Box giri più e più volte come se fosse stata lubrificata.

(in english... translated by 3D-ME = Kyle Randall... thank you, Kyle!!!) you need:
  • 2 nuts (8mm diameter, I prefer to use brass nuts)
  • 2 flat washers (8mm diameter)
  • 1 compression spring (10mm inside diameter, 22mm length, the important is that, the spring, compressed to about 18cm in length exerts a thrust of not more than 0.5Kg, because a greater strength between the two nuts can compromise the smoothness of rotation of the rod)
  • 4 screws (3mm diameter, 40mm length)
  • 4 flat washers (3mm diameter)
  • 4 nuts (3mm diameter)
  • 8 screws (3mm diameter, 20mm length)
  • 8 flat washers (3mm diameter)
  • 8 toothed washers (3mm diameter)
  • 8 nuts (3mm diameter)
  • 8 compression springs (4mm diameter, 10mm length)
  • 2 screws (5mm diameter, 50mm length or more)
    • You must print:
  • Mod1a (1 copy)
  • Mod1b (2 copies)
  • Mod1c (1 copy)
  • Mod1d (1 copy)
  • Mod2a (2 copies)
  • Mod2b (2 copies)
  • Mod2c (2 copies)
  • Mod2d (1 copy)
I put 15 photos in the gallery with the assembly sequence.

Attention, please
Once the assembly is finished and placed on the bar, the Z-Box must rotate freely, without effort. To test this, hold the bar vertically, and make sure that there is a slight lateral thrust as the Z-Box rotates, as if it had been oiled.

title: Vertical Text - Spiff at a 45 degree angle

description.text:
Extruding at 45 degrees means your polygons can be printed on a vertical face. Use linear_extrude_45 the same way as linear_extrude in your OpenSCAD code.  
There are two modes: standalone extrusion, or shallow. Shallow mode is meant to be added or subtracted from a vertical face.  
I've added an implementation for Spiff so you can have vertical text.
Download Spiff from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:106256 Download files from this thing and put them in the same folder with Spiff.

title: RobotDigg Spool holder with 608ZZ skate bearing inserts

description.text: I could not find anything on Thingiverse that fit my RobotDigg PLA spools so I made this 4 mm thick spool holder, quick print. With a small mod you could adapt it to fit any 200 mm diameter spools.  Fits 21.93 mm diameter skate bearings, nice friction fit with a taper at the back to keep the bearing from being pushed into the spool. The Robot Digg spools Have a 38.14 mm diameter hole. 104 mm from center to base so fits the 200 mm diameter Robot Digg spool. The cross members are a tight fit so tapping them on with a small hammer and a drop of crazy glue makes a nice strong connection. Leave the little bag of desiccant in the spool so it doesn't back spool, the bearings are very smooth. I'm using a 6.26 mm bolt in the pic but it is sized for 7.75 mm threaded rod.

Print it, tap the cross supports on, put a drop of crazy glue at the connection. Press in  the bearings, put them in the reel and thread a bolt or section of threaded rod with a couple washers through the whole thing. Leave the little bag of desiccant inside the spool so it doesn't back spool.

Stompbox for a heaphone amp or other single pot effect. I probably have enough parts to build another few. Ping me if you need something specific. OpenSCAD files at https://github.com/mkellner/openscad

The stripboard layout and some information about the circuit can be found here: http://tagboardeffects.blogspot.com/2013/01/mxr-headphone-amp.html I printed the box and foot, then used aluminum tape to shield the box. After I loaded the .dxf file, I screen captured it, and pasted that into Photoshop. I then sized the image to match the size of the box to get the appropriate dimensions for the label. I then layered up the label and printed on label media with a color laser printer. After applying the sticker, I then used a few layers of high-gloss glaze over it to give the label some durability. Let dry well. Then to wiring the offboard components to the board. Standard stompbox fare. There is a slot for the poteniometer tab. 3pdt switch and led at the bottom, pot at the top. 1/4" jacks on either side and 9v connector at the top. Careful for connections touching either the aluminum shielding or other components. Tape or otherwise insulate the pc board.

I needed a rugged dependable battery holder for an audio project. None of the stuff on thingiverse seemed awesome enough, so I made this!  
To build, you'll need some hard plastic like PLA, ABS, whatever. I used ColorFabb regular white. You'll also need some rubbery material. I used PolyMakr PolyFlex, which works great on an unmodified replicator 2. You will also need three 4G countersunk screws and ideally one pan head 4G screw for the negative terminal. Use brass countersunk screws and zink pan head for neat golden positive silver negative colouring!  
To attach wires, simply place the wire through the screw hole before screwing in the screw. You can also easily clip alligator clips on to the screws for easy experiments!

I've been using these OpenSCAD modules in my models, developing new parts for my different projects. I decided to compile the parts into one library and release it into the Thingiverse wild. Several people have been looking for printable washers and nyloc nuts recently, and have released them as individual things. Also, someone just asked me for specs on the dovetail I used on my makerbottable filament spool. All of these things are in my library, including: Shape primitives
Hexagrams,
Equilateral triangles (prisms),
3 sided pyramids and tetrahedrons,
4 sided pyramids including a Johnson's Solid square pyramid (a cube cut along its diagonal),
tubes (hollow cylinders with variable wall thicknesses),
slots with selectable round or square end(s),
teardrop (as designed by whosawhatsis, www.thingiverse.com/thing:3457)
dovetail pins and slots to attach parts without connectors,
rounded corner rectangles, and
keyhole slots.
The rounded rectangles and keyholes can be seen my quick release x-Rod caps, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4765
The dovetails can be seen on my Makerbottable filament Spool, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4337 Hardware Parts
Hex Nuts,
Washers,
Cap Bolts,
Hex Bolts, and
Bearings These parts are modeled by the part's name or size for mockups or to difference out voids in a model. For instance hexNut("M6") will give the appropriate sized hardware. The sizes are included in an extensible table, so if you have a specific part, you can just add it's dimension, name it, and use it. Miscellaneous functions and useful stuff
I included a function that will globally adjust the number of triangles used in rounded objects based upon a single "displayMode" variable. For screen display, spheres will be facetless, but by changing only one variable, you can reduce the facet count for printing to about 1mm resolution. Several functions to rotate and translate objects in only one plane, with names that (to me) are easy to remember. for instance, rotate(tighten()) will twist an object along the z plane clockwise 90 degrees (like tightening a lid on a jar). Likewise Push() moves an object away, Slide() to the side, and Lift() up. Last, is a rudimentary table module and access functions (alluded to under the hardware section). You can put any data in the table, with a named header row, add names for the various columns in a column table, and subsequently locate all of the data in that row or any individual entry by using the functions tableRow(rowName) or tableEntry(rowName, columnName). The library has a selection of bearings, and both metric and US bolts/washers/nuts included, but you can always add more. The table can be used for just about anything, including positions within your model that you can refer to like this: translate(tableRow("Front Tire Position"); I hope you like it and if you have upgrade ideas, e-mail me and I'll try to incorporate the changes here. If you REALLY like it, feel free to flattr it. :o) UPDATE New version uploaded on 5/7/11, old version removed. Fixed bug in bearing() module that doubled the expected size (used diameter as radius). Added rezPrinter and rezScreen functions for adjusting facet sizes.

1) Download the Libs.scad file and put it in the same location as your project file.
2) Use the command include <"Libs.scad"> at the start of your file to access the library -
3) Just use the modules like you would use your own. For a demo (the STL you see here) use the command libDemo();
the command libHelp(); will echo the prototype of all modules to the console.
the command libMoveHelp(); will echo the rotation and translation function names to the console.

description.text:
A holder for 17ml acrylic paint dropper bottles as used by brands like vallejo, reaper or army painter.
The holder is fully parametric (number of rows/columns, hole diameter, height, etc. can be changed with just one variable each) and multiple holders can easily be stacked.

• Printing one of the smaller versions of the thing first is highly recommended as some printers might have troubles with the many overhangs.
  • Print it on its side
  • Also the holder is fully parametric: everything from the number of columns and rows to the diameter of the holes can easily be changed; however, the placement of extra support pillars works best with uneven numbers of rows. To do so just enter the CoffeeScript sourcecode (dropper_bottle_holder.coffee) into CoffeeSCad at http://kaosat-dev.github.com/CoffeeSCad/.

title: Dual Radial blower mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
During my endless fan mount building phase I created this.  It holds two 40mm radial fans (Makerbot style).  They proved to be OVERKILL!!!  I had to throttle them back to 40-50% power to prevent the hotend from loosing heat.   But overall it worked out and its the mount system I ended up sticking with.  
The tips I didn't include in the downloads.  I ended up running mine without tips.
123d design

comments.text: This is fascinating to me. I was unhappy with my cooling setup and I happened to have a couple of these  blowers i had salvaged from something a while back. So I designed my own mount for them. Now I stumble across yours and its almost the exact same design. I was happy with mine but yours is more robust and looks better too. Im going to give yours a try. I suppose its no suprise how when presented with the same problem on the same printer two different people with the same fans will find the same solution. Still funny though.

A scissor arm that is printed preassembled! A lot of fun to play with.

Carefully level your plate to avoid bonding between parts on the first layer. After printing, the joints will likely not move. Apply a gentle force to them - I typically apply a bit of rotation and shear stress to each in turn. At some point, by exerting a gentle pressure on the two extremities, the joints become free and the fun begins! Be careful to apply only gentle stress at first or you may break one of the hinge joint (happened to me a couple time, but I tried to adjust the tolerance to reduce the risk).
This is a parametric model created in my own software (soon to be released). I include the script for reference, it should be easy to convert to OpenSCAD if needed. In the meantime I also include the STL for the shown model, as well as the csg file from which it was generated (can be imported in OpenSCAD). I include G-Code for a Replicator 1 (with Sailfish firmware) -- use at your own risk since it will likely not work on a different printer.
I printed it in ABS, at 0.2mm layer thickness, 120 mm/s travel and 60 mm/sec print speed. These are the settings used in the provided gcode.
Have fun!

title: makergear m2 adjustable bed corner clamp

description.text: these corners adjust to your glass removing any play so you no longer need any binder clips. print a set of 4 of these. the screws dont need to be tight. they should not apply pressure to the glass or mic6. they should only take play or movement out of the bed. the hole is for an m3 screw size. i suggest the hole is cleaned up with a drill bit and tapped to the correct thread or atleast drilled out so the screw can just make its own threads into the plastic. i suggest printing these in abs or epc at 100% infill. for the newer REV E printers use this version here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1217210

comments.text: Thank you sir, nicely done.
comments.author: MidTenMaker

comments.text: the adjusters on the corner clamp should never make contact with the bed heater because the makergear bed heater is slightly undersized from the build platform. it will always contact the build plate first. they should work great just as they are with either an alum or the stock glass plate.
comments.author: Mrcleanr6

comments.text: Thanks I should have gone a little further with the assembly before asking, they work great thanks!
comments.author: Mrcleanr6

comments.text: The bed corner clamp does not clear the top of my aluminum heatspreader, it looks like it is short about the same thickness of the silicone heater pad. Am I missing something? I was going to modify the stl so it fits, but wondering if i'm doing something wrong.
comments.author: goopyplastic

comments.text: Some info, the spread/bed rest to the bottom of the cornerclamp is 3.26mm in your design, my heatspreader with silicon heater is a hair over 4mm.
comments.author: goopyplastic

comments.text: Has using the plastic instead of rubber caused you any issues?  I'd expect that the rubber does a better job of handling thermal growth.
comments.author: akkrolnik

comments.text: not in the slightest. these are by far one of the best enhancements i have done to my 3 m2's. feedback from other people using them has been great too. nothing bad. so far everyone seems to like them. any thermal growth of glass or aluminum is going to be on the x/y plane so remember these are adjustable in that plane. with that said though i have noticed no tension difference from when the bed is hot or cold using either glass or mic6 aluminum. these do need to be printed in abs. my first set pas petg and the non stop high heat was just making them too soft.
comments.author: akkrolnik

comments.text: Great Idea! Would it hurt to print these in PLA?
comments.author: Volcom7114

comments.text: yes, you cant do these out of pla. remember these will be in direct contact with the hot bed. pla turns to mush just getting it warm. it must be done in abs.
comments.author: Volcom7114

author: Mrcleanr6

description.text: Owl with hanging loop

Hold the acrylic cover on. DIY video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S4BDq3_Wbt8

This is the first thing I created in MeshLab and I am really pleased with the results.
My wife wants a bowl of these different sizes and colors on the table.
The cat also loves playing with it, it has a peculiar roll and sound in a tile floor.
If you start by making a small ball you can put it inside a large ball when printing(make sure it is below the print head height when inserted.

I use Simplify 3d as my slicer. I import it in, scale it to the size I want and rotate it so there is a good footprint on the bed. I have my start height at .2 mm so it just sits flater. See image from slicer if you have a pentagon flat on the table it sticks really well.
I just use Glue stick and 40 degrees C bed temp.
PLA
190 degrees
.2 mm layers
40mm/sec feed
2 bottom, top and perimeter layers with 10% rectilinear fill.
No support needed.
I have a big fan blowing over the print area.
Very few fluffy bits to clean up.

comments.text: Cura 2.1.2 wouldn't even show the model of the stl file, never mind trying to slice it.
comments.author: ToddZebert

comments.text: Looks like you use Simplify3D - so do I.  But you mentioned you did not use supports.  Just wondering how you dialed in your retraction settings because you ended up with a very nice quality result.
comments.author: tri-lite

comments.text:
Yes I do use S3D. I haven't really played with retraction settings just use the default for my printer leapfrog Creatr, The retraction distance is 0.5 mm Extra restart 0 vertical lift 0 retrat speed 30mm/s no coasting or wipe. I also run PLA at 205 degrees c.
I don't bother with a nozzle fan, I just have a big domestic 10inch fan blowing over the bed.
Hope that helps.
comments.author: tri-lite

comments.text: It's great that you have such a high quality level with default settings.  Your PLA temp is a bit higher than I run, so I'll give that a try.  Thanks for providing the details.
comments.author: Oggie

comments.text: is this a big ball or not
comments.author: Sarah2002

comments.text: It can be as big as you want Sarah. I just scale it to the size I want judging it by the preview in the slicer program, about 100mm/10cm seems to print a good size without the need for support.
comments.author: Sarah2002

remixed_from.author: MrJohn
remixed_from.title: United States Marine Corps Rank Insignias

title: United States Marine Corps Desk Plaque

description.text: This is a desk name plaque that I designed for some friends as work. The EGAs on the sides and the rank insignia in the middle are all removable so that it can be packed up nice and neat. Also the pieces are interchangeable. I am putting up the ranks that I have put together in another make. Thanks to MrJohn's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16439 which I derrived the ranks from when I was just learning CAD and heavily modified to optimize printability. As well I expanded the collection to include all ranks from Sergeant to Sergeant Major.

In order to get the name curved onto the base using Sketchup, I used Chris Fullmer's Shape Bender plugin. http://extensions.sketchup.com/en/content/clf-shape-bender Go ahead, go download it now, you know you want to :) For the gold highlight, originally I was gold leafing the letters, however I found this wonderful liquid gold leaf paint that looks every bit as good but takes about an nth of the effort.
